text: Hi, I’m Troy McClure. You might remember me from such films as The Day the Peacock Died. After filming scenes with feathered co-stars all day, there’s nothing I enjoy more than a bucket of Buster’s Chicken. It’s chickentastic!

text: Mr. Stark's idea for implementing affirmative action in the university's admission process is complete folly. He say's he wants the student body to represent diversity in the community. But that's ridiculous. I suppose this means we'll have to throw out our academic standards while were at it. After all, if we're going to let students into our prestigious institution just because of their gender or the color of their skin, then what's going to happen to our reputation?
label: fallacy of extension

text: "If we ban Hummers because they are bad for the environment, then eventually the government will ban all cars; therefore, we should not ban Hummers."
label: faulty generalization

text: Poetry is a based on rhythm, and music is based on rhythm, so isn't poetry a kind of music?
label: fallacy of logic

text: All useless laws, such as Reform Bill 13, should be repealed.
label: circular reasoning

text: "Russia has a terrible human rights record." "Well, the United States has done plenty of bad things." -the President when confronted about Russia's human rights abuses.
label: fallacy of relevance

text: America keeps telling China to be more respecting of journalism, but why don't they stop the American propaganda first?
label: ad hominem

text: “President Jones raised taxes, and then the rate of violent crime went up. Jones is responsible for the rise in crime.”
label: false causality

text: First senator: The nation is in debt and we should not add to the defense budget. Second senator: I cannot believe you want to leave the nation defenseless!
label: fallacy of extension

text: Bill says Jenny would make a good class president, but Bill makes bad grades, so we shouldn’t vote for Jenny.
label: ad hominem

text: Going to prom (when you don't want to) because 90 percent of your classmates are going
label: ad populum

text: If we allow our 14 year-old to have her first date tonight, what's next? A wedding, kids?
label: faulty generalization

text: Two members of my team have become more engaged employees after taking public speaking classes. That proves we should have mandatory public speaking classes for the whole company to improve employee engagement.
label: faulty generalization

text: Thanks to her enduring popularity with employees, Annie Smith is the best-liked CEO in our company's history.
label: ad hominem

text: Whilst rallying support for his plan to fundamentally undermine citizens' rights, the Supreme Leader told the people they were either on his side, or they were on the side of the enemy.
label: false dilemma

text: Either you can save your money to buy a new car for yourself, or you can just take an Uber around for the rest of your life.
label: false dilemma

text: It is said that we have a good understanding of our universe.  Therefore, we know exactly how it began and exactly when.
label: equivocation

text: The greatest thing that we can do is to love each other. Love is better than any other emotion.
label: circular reasoning

text: "The Philippines is in poverty because of poor people."
label: circular reasoning

text: Old Major's speech claiming that ALL the animals will unite and revolt against the humans
label: ad populum

text: Everyone is getting tattoos in college, so you might as well do it too.
label: ad populum

text: “If you really loved me, you would buy me everything I ever wanted!”
label: false dilemma

text: If you don’t like Lady Gaga, it’s because you hate women.
label: fallacy of extension

text: “I didn’t see you at the charity fundraiser today. I guess you are not a good person after all.”
label: false dilemma

text: Why should we put people on trial when we know they are guilty?
label: circular reasoning

text: I asked six of my friends what they thought of the new spending restraints and they agreed it is a good idea. The new restraints are therefore generally popular.
label: faulty generalization

text: Shakira is the best singer in the world because she is the most talented singer there is.
label: circular reasoning

text: Braden, you drive a beat-up car from the 1980s. For this reason, we can never allow you to be a lifeguard at the community pool.
label: ad hominem

text: Order is necessary to justice because justice can only be achieved by a program of social and legal order.
label: circular reasoning

text: “We can give cadets awards for doing well, or we can have a disciplined squadron. We can’t do both.”
label: false dilemma

text: You can't prove that mermaids actually don't exist and therefore it's reasonable to say that they do
label: intentional

text: involves acceptance or rejection of concepts based on their source, not their merit
label: ad hominem

text: Falsely requiring an opponent to “disprove” instead of you “proving” your argument
label: intentional

text: Hillary Clinton wants to take your guns away, and she wants to abolish the Second Amendment.
label: false dilemma

text: All ghosts are imaginary. All unicorns are imaginary. Therefore, all ghosts are unicorns.
label: fallacy of logic

text: Oh, please. What do you know about labor laws? You don't even have a job.
label: ad hominem

text: one thing leads to another and another and another. . . creates a “snowball” effect.
label: faulty generalization

text: “Police officers agree that Blackjack Steering Wheel Locks are the most effective deterrent against car theft.”
label: fallacy of credibility

text: "I am not unmindful that some of you have come here out of great trials and tribulations. Some of you have come fresh from narrow jail cells. And some of you have come from areas where your quest -- quest for freedom left you battered by the storms of persecution and staggered by the winds of police brutality. You have been the veterans of creative suffering. Continue to work with the faith that unearned suffering is redemptive. Go back to Mississippi, go back to Alabama, go back to South Carolina, go back to Georgia, go back to Louisiana, go back to the slums and ghettos of our northern cities, knowing that somehow this situation can and will be changed."  Which appeal is the primary appeal used in this quote?
label: appeal to emotion

text: We shouldn’t put her in jail even if she stole billions of pesos. She is already too old to be locked up.
label: appeal to emotion

text: Either God created the world or evolution happened. Evolution happened. Therefore, God did not create the world.
label: fallacy of logic

text: All writing teachers must be awesome because Ms. Lopez is.
label: faulty generalization

text: Many democrats don't want a border wall with Mexico, which means they don't want to keep Americans safe
label: fallacy of extension

text: You can't believe Jack when he says there is a God because he doesn't even have a job.
label: ad hominem

text: I hated the movie because it was the worst movie I ever saw.
label: circular reasoning

text: Lebron James, one of the most decorated basketball players of all time, says you need to eat breakfast so you need to eat breakfast
label: fallacy of credibility

text: The speaker or writer appeals to the audience's trust by establishing his credibility or trustworthiness as a writer or speaker?
label: fallacy of credibility

text: The economy grows as the number of likes on my Instagram account continue to increase. Clearly, the two are linked.
label: false causality

text: "Four legs good, two legs bad"
label: ad populum

text: This theory originally occurred to a scientist in the form of a dream; therefore it cannot be valid.
label: ad hominem

text: My family is this school's biggest donor so, you better think about that bad grade you gave me on my test.
label: appeal to emotion

text: A commercial about abandoned animals needing a shelter of a forever home. They ask for a small donation to help these struggling animals.
label: appeal to emotion

text: assumes that short-term deviations will correct themselves
label: false causality

text: The economy continues to grow as the number of "likes" on my Instagram account continue to increase. Clearly, the two are linked.
label: false causality

text: You should never gamble. Once you start gambling you find it hard to stop. Soon you are spending all your money on gambling, and eventually you will turn to crime to support your earnings.
label: faulty generalization

text: Yesterday you were 5 minutes late, today 10, and tomorrow you won't even show up!
label: faulty generalization

text: I lost my phone in the living room, so it will always be in the living room when it is lost.
label: circular reasoning

text: Senator Ribbit is a liar. You shouldn't listen to him on anything.
label: ad hominem

text: I heard that the Catholic Church was involved in a sex scandal cover-up.  Therefore, my 102-year-old Catholic neighbor, who frequently attends Church, is guilty as well!
label: faulty generalization

text: This makes you think you need to believe or buy something because everyone else is. Which technique is it?
label: ad populum

text: "You shouldn't go to 'Vomito' I went once and the food was awful." is
label: faulty generalization

text: When asked about his comments Trump made on his tape with Billy Bush, Trump responded, “It’s locker room talk, and it’s one of those things. I will knock the hell out of ISIS. We’re going to defeat ISIS. ISIS happened a number of years ago in a vacuum that was left because of bad judgment. And I will tell you, I will take care of ISIS.”
label: fallacy of relevance

text: Either we pass this ordinance or there will be rioting in the streets.
label: false dilemma

text: Taco is the best because it tastes better.
label: circular reasoning

text: Sam is riding her bike in her home town in Maine, minding her own business. A station wagon comes up behind her and the driver starts beeping his horn and then tries to force her off the road. As he goes by, the driver yells "get on the sidewalk where you belong!" Sam sees that the car has Ohio plates and concludes that all Ohio drivers are jerks.
label: faulty generalization

text: The Bible clearly says, “Thou shall not bear false witness.” Therefore, as a Christian, you better answer the door and tell our drunk neighbor with the shotgun, that his wife, whom he is looking to kill, is hiding in our basement. Otherwise, you are defying God himself!
label: faulty generalization

text: Smoking pot is against the law because it's wrong; I know it's wrong because it is against the law.
label: circular reasoning

text: Since many of the students at St. Cloud State University get A's, St. Cloud State must  be a top-rated school.
label: faulty generalization

text: "It rained and then we lost the game. Every time it rains, we're going to lose."
label: false causality

text: "You cannot detain me. I am still grieving my cat's death."
label: appeal to emotion

text: Why shouldn't I gossip about Laura Jane? You know she talks about us every chance she gets.
label: fallacy of relevance

text: Vote for Smith or live through four more years of higher taxes.
label: false dilemma

text: "In its origins [AIDS] was entirely a disease of sodomites... That the first case was diagnosed a little over a decade after the so-called "Gay Rights" and "Gay Pride" movement gained momentum and force can hardly be coincidental." - Harry Jaffa, Professor Emeritus of Political Philosophy at Claremont McKenna College
label: false causality

text: Karen: I am sorry, but if you think man used to ride dinosaurs, then you are obviously not very well educated. Kent:  First of all, I hold a PhD in creation science, so I am well-educated.  Second of all, your ad hominem attack shows that you are wrong, and man did use to ride dinosaurs. Karen:  Getting your PhD in a couple of months, from a “college” in a trailer park, is not being well-educated.  My fallacy in no way is evidence for man riding on dinosaurs, and despite what you may think, the Flintstone’s was not a documentary!
label: fallacy of logic

text: Like many issues in the world, what seems to be the biggest ISSUE among the Climate Change DEBATE?
label: fallacy of extension

text: If Mr. Stiedemann assigns us homework then I can't work on other assignments in my other classes. Then my teachers will get mad and cause me to get angry. Then my anger will lead to behavioral issues and I'll get suspended.
label: faulty generalization

text: You are clearly just too young to understand this issue!
label: ad hominem

text: Wife: Should we buy the house? Husband: The Realtor didn’t say anything about any problems, so I am sure it is fine. Let’s get it!
label: faulty generalization

text: Incorrectly thinking that one thing leads to another
label: false causality

text: "Everybody is late coming back from lunch, so it shouldn't matter if I'm late."
label: ad populum

text: "University of Virginia professor [Charlotte] Patterson, considered a leading researcher in the field, says she has reviewed 22 studies involving offspring of gays ranging from toddlers to adults. She found none convincing [sic] that the children had suffered or were more than normally inclined to be gay. [...] Conservatives discredit Patterson by pointing out that she is an acknowledged lesbian, with a presumed ideological interest in the subject she studies."
label: ad hominem

text: Steve: I think it is fantastic that you and Sylvia are getting married! Chuck: I cannot believe you think my getting married only exists in my imagination!  That is what fantastic means, after all.
label: equivocation

text: What persuasive technique is being used in this photo?
label: ad populum

text: Jimmy has a fever, sinus congestion, a cough, and can’t come to school, so he probably has a test later today.
label: false causality

text: I broke my mirror this morning, AND I failed my History test. I must've failed because the mirror gave me bad luck.
label: false causality

text: I know that our TV advertisements are more effective than radio. The numbers show that we hit twice the audience with TV, and our focus groups remember the TV commercial 38 percent more than the radio slot.
label: faulty generalization

text: "I knew him in high school and he almost flunked out. He can't be a good choice for mayor."
label: ad hominem

text: By rejecting God, you are rejecting goodness, kindness, and love itself.
label: appeal to emotion

text: "My opponent raises a really good point, but can we really trust him? He moved to this town three years ago and everyone knows his wife left him.
label: ad hominem

text: Hybrid cars are like solar power, full of promise but too expensive. We’ll never be able to build affordable hybrid cars.
label: fallacy of logic

text: I know in my heart of hearts that our home team will win the World Series.
label: appeal to emotion

text: The number of pirates in existence decreased as the global average temperature rose. Therefore, we can conclude that hotter weather reduces piracy.
label: circular reasoning

text: "I stay away from those gatherings because I don't want to be brainwashed."
label: circular reasoning

text: Aaron Rodgers says you should get State Farm Insurance on your home, car, motorcycle, or trailer!
label: fallacy of credibility

text: Lola: I don't think John would be a good fit to manage this project, because he doesn't have a lot of experience with project management. John: But you don't have a lot of experience in project management either!
label: ad hominem

text: An opinion article in a campus newspaper states that in an all-campus survey 95% of students think that tuition should be lowered and therefore tuition should be lowered immediately.
label: ad populum

text: You ask your mother if you can go to the mall with your friends. She says "no". You ask why? She says, "because I'm the mom and I say so".
label: fallacy of credibility

text: An environmental group illegally blocked loggers and workers at a nuclear plant. Therefore, environmentalists are radicals who take the law into their own hands.
label: faulty generalization

text: Decriminalizing marijuana turns the U.S. into a stoner nation
label: faulty generalization

text: If we can send a woman into outerspace and communicate with them while they are there, then surely we can learn to communicate with one another in our state.
label: fallacy of logic

text: “No one has ever been able to prove definitively that extra-terrestrials exist, so they must not be real.”
label: intentional

text: The priest told me I should have faith. I have faith that my son will do well in school this year. Therefore, the priest should be happy with me.
label: equivocation

text: President Bush argues that we should open up the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for oil drilling. But Bush just wants to reward his rich cronies in the oil industry, so we can't take his arguments seriously.
label: ad hominem

text: "The research I found on cell phone use in the classroom suggests that students can be distracted when they have access to texting. This leads me to believe that all high school students should not be allowed to have their phones on them at school anytime.
label: fallacy of logic

text: My best friend says you’re a liar, so I’m not going to talk to you.
label: ad hominem

text: People who are psychotic act in a bizarre manner. This person acts in a bizarre manner. Therefore: This person is psychotic.
label: fallacy of logic

text: Since it was a deathbed confession, it must be true.
label: ad hominem

text: Speaker 1: I think we should have single payer, universal, health care. Speaker 2: Communist countries tried that. We don’t want America to be a communist country. We shouldn’t have single payer health care.
label: fallacy of extension

text: If I make an exception for you then I'll have to make an exception for everyone
label: faulty generalization

text: All this time that you're telling me to improve, you're being lazy yourself.
label: ad hominem

text: I have a red car. My car was in a wreck. Therefore, all red cars get wrecked.
label: faulty generalization

text: If we let the government implant tracking devices in criminals, it's not going to stop there! They're going to want to track school children and eventually everyone!
label: faulty generalization

text: "My best friend tweeted about the health benefits of pizza, and so we're going to out to eat two vegetable pizzas tonight."
label: fallacy of credibility

text: The uncommunicative strangers seemed unwilling to speak to us, hiding behind the language barrier.
label: appeal to emotion

text: If I have cable, then I have seen a naked lady. I don’t have cable. Therefore, I have never seen a naked lady.
label: fallacy of logic

text: Santa has a red suit. My dad has a red suit. My dad must be Santa Claus!
label: fallacy of logic

text: Sarah loves to wear running shoes, all girls must like to run.
label: faulty generalization

text: If we use one more can of hairspray this month, the ozone layer will not exist, and we will not exist!
label: faulty generalization

text: When the new administration came on campus, test scores increased and attendance improved.
label: false causality

text: Same-sex marriage must be prohibited, or the family structure as we know it will  collapse.
label: appeal to emotion

text: politicians coin names to cast blame
label: ad hominem

text: Senator Li announced today that she plans to cut funding to early childhood education programs. The last thing we need is a government official who hates children!
label: fallacy of extension

text: only man is rational. no women is man. Therefore, no women is rational
label: equivocation
